query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue, 2 se glorïar di te la gente fai 3 qua giù dove l’affetto nostro langue,
4 mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai: 5 ché là dove appetito non si torce, 6 dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.
query.result:
1 O little our nobility of blood, 2 if you make the people boast of you 3 down here where our affection languishes,
4 a marvelous thing it will never be to me: 5 because where appetite is not twisted, 6 I say in heaven, I boasted of it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Ben se’ tu manto che tosto raccorce: 8 sì che, se non s’appon di dì in die, 9 lo tempo va dintorno con le force.
query.result: 7 Well are you a cloak that quickly shortens: 8 so that, if it is not added day by day, 9 time goes around with the forces.

10 From ‘you’ who first offered himself in Rome, 11 in which his family perseveres less, 12 my words began again;
13 whence Beatrice, who was a little free, 14 laughing, seemed the one who coughed 15 at the first written fault of Geneva.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Per tanti rivi s’empie d’allegrezza 20 la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia 21 perché può sostener che non si spezza.
query.result: 19 Through so many streams is filled with joy 20 my mind, which makes joy of itself 21 because it can sustain that it does not break.

22 Tell me therefore, my dear first fruit, 23 what were your ancients and what were the years 24 that were marked in your childhood;
25 tell me of the sheepfold of Saint John 26 how old it was then, and who were the people 27 among it worthy of higher seats.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Come s’avviva a lo spirar d’i venti 29 carbone in fiamma, così vid’ io quella 30 luce risplendere a’ miei blandimenti;
31 e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella, 32 così con voce più dolce e soave, 33 ma non con questa moderna favella,
34 dissemi: «Da quel dì che fu detto ‘Ave’ 35 al parto in che mia madre, ch’è or santa, 36 s’allevïò di me ond’ era grave,
37 al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta 38 e trenta fiate venne questo foco 39 a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.
query.result:
28 As coal is enlivened by the breathing of the winds 29 in flame, thus I saw that light 30 shine at my pleas;
31 and as it became more beautiful to my eyes, 32 thus with a sweeter and softer voice, 33 but not with this modern speech,
34 it said to me: «From the day that ‘Hail’ was said 35 to the birth in which my mother, who is now holy, 36 relieved herself of me, where she was heavy,
37 to his Leon five hundred and fifty 38 and thirty times this fire 39 came to rekindle itself under his plant.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco 41 dove si truova pria l’ultimo sesto 42 da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.
query.result: 40 My ancients and I were born in the place 41 where is found first the last sixth 42 from those that run your annual game.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Basti d’i miei maggiori udirne questo: 44 chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi, 45 più è tacer che ragionare onesto.
query.result: 43 Let it suffice to hear this of my ancestors: 44 who they were and whence they came here, 45 it is more honest to be silent than to reason.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Tutti color ch’a quel tempo eran ivi 47 da poter arme tra Marte e ’l Batista, 48 eran il quinto di quei ch’or son vivi.
query.result: 46 All those who were there at that time 47 to be able to bear arms between Mars and the Baptist, 48 were the fifth of those who are now alive.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Ma la cittadinanza, ch’è or mista 50 di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine, 51 pura vediesi ne l’ultimo artista.
query.result: 49 But the citizenry, which is now mixed 50 of Campi, of Certaldo and of Fegghine, 51 was seen pure in the last artist.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine 53 quelle genti ch’io dico, e al Galluzzo 54 e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,
55 che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo 56 del villan d’Aguglion, di quel da Signa, 57 che già per barattare ha l’occhio aguzzo!
58 Se la gente ch’al mondo più traligna 59 non fosse stata a Cesare noverca, 60 ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,
61 tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca, 62 che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti, 63 là dove andava l’avolo a la cerca;
64 sariesi Montemurlo ancor de’ Conti; 65 sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d’Acone, 66 e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.
query.result:
52 Oh, how much better it would be to be near 53 those people that I say, and to Galluzzo 54 and to Trespiano have your border,
55 than to have them inside and endure the stench 56 of the peasant of Aguglion, of that from Signa, 57 who already has a sharp eye to barter!
58 If the people who in the world most betray 59 had not been Caesar’s sister-in-law, 60 but like a mother to her son benign,
61 such a thing is Florentine and changes and sells, 62 that it would have turned to Semifonte, 63 there where the grandfather went to seek;
64 Montemurlo would still be of the Counts; 65 the Cerchi would be in the pieve of Acone, 66 and perhaps in Valdigrieve the Buondelmonti.

67 Always the confusion of the people 68 was the beginning of the evil of the city, 69 as is your food that is applied;
70 and a blind bull falls more quickly 71 than a blind lamb; and often cuts 72 more and better one than the five swords.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia 74 come sono ite, e come se ne vanno 75 di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,
76 udir come le schiatte si disfanno 77 non ti parrà nova cosa né forte, 78 poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.
query.result:
73 If you look at Luni and Orbisaglia 74 how they are gone, and how they go 75 behind them Chiusi and Sinigaglia,
76 you will hear how the families are undone 77 will not seem a new thing nor strong to you, 78 since the cities have an end.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte, 80 sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna 81 che dura molto, e le vite son corte.
query.result: 79 Your things all have their death, 80 just as you; but it hides in some 81 that lasts a long time, and the lives are short.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 E come ’l volger del ciel de la luna 83 cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa, 84 così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:
85 per che non dee parer mirabil cosa 86 ciò ch’io dirò de li alti Fiorentini 87 onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.
query.result:
82 And as the turning of the sky of the moon 83 covers and uncovers the shores without rest, 84 thus does Fortune with Florence:
85 for which it should not seem a marvelous thing 86 what I will say of the high Florentines 87 whose fame is hidden in time.

88 I saw the Ughi and I saw the Catellini, 89 Filippi, Greeks, Ormanni and Alberichi, 90 already in decline, illustrious citizens;
91 and I saw as great as the ancients, 92 with that of the Sannella, that of the Ark, 93 and Soldanieri and Ardinghi and Bostichi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Sovra la porta ch’al presente è carca 95 di nova fellonia di tanto peso 96 che tosto fia iattura de la barca,
97 erano i Ravignani, ond’ è disceso 98 il conte Guido e qualunque del nome 99 de l’alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.
query.result:
94 Above the gate that at present is laden 95 with new treachery of such weight 96 that soon it will be an ill omen for the boat,
97 were the Ravignani, from whom descended 98 count Guido and whoever of the name 99 of the high Bellincione has since taken.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come 101 regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio 102 dorata in casa sua già l’elsa e ’l pome.
query.result: 100 That of the Pressa already knew how 101 to hold oneself as one wishes, and had Galigaio 102 gilded in his house already the hilt and the pommel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Grand’ era già la colonna del Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci 105 e Galli e quei ch’arrossan per lo staio.
query.result: 103 Great already was the column of the Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti and Barucci 105 and Galli and those who blush for the measure.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci 107 era già grande, e già eran tratti 108 a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.
query.result: 106 The stock from which the Calfucci arose 107 was already great, and already were drawn 108 to the curule Sizii and Arrigucci.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti 110 per lor superbia! e le palle de l’oro 111 fiorian Fiorenza in tutt’ i suoi gran fatti.
query.result: 109 Oh, what I saw those who are undone 110 because of their pride! And the balls of gold 111 flourished Florence in all its great deeds.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Così facieno i padri di coloro 113 che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca, 114 si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.
query.result: 112 Thus did the fathers of those 113 who, whenever your church is vacant, 114 make themselves fat staying in consistory.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 L’oltracotata schiatta che s’indraca 116 dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra ’l dente 117 o ver la borsa, com’ agnel si placa,
118 già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente; 119 sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato 120 che poï il suocero il fé lor parente.
query.result:
115 The overbearing lineage that becomes entangled 116 behind whoever flees, and whoever shows the tooth 117 or indeed the purse, as a lamb is appeased,
118 already was coming up, but of small people; 119 so that it did not please Ubertin Donato 120 who then made the father-in-law their relative.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Già era ’l Caponsacco nel mercato 122 disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era 123 buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.
query.result: 121 Already was Caponsacco in the market 122 descended from Fiesole, and already was 123 good citizen Judas and Infangato.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera: 125 nel picciol cerchio s’entrava per porta 126 che si nomava da quei de la Pera.
query.result: 124 I will tell a thing incredible and true: 125 into the small circle one entered by gate 126 that was named by those of the Pear.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta 128 del gran barone il cui nome e ’l cui pregio 129 la festa di Tommaso riconforta,
130 da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio; 131 avvegna che con popol si rauni 132 oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.
query.result:
127 Each one who bears the beautiful insignia 128 of the great baron whose name and whose worth 129 the feast of Thomas comforts,
130 from him had military service and privilege; 131 although now with the people he gathers 132 today he who wears the sash with the device.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni; 134 e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto, 135 se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.

Please translate each line literally into English.
136 La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto, 137 per lo giusto disdegno che v’ha morti 138 e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,
139 era onorata, essa e suoi consorti: 140 o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti 141 le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!
142 Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi, 143 se Dio t’avesse conceduto ad Ema 144 la prima volta ch’a città venisti.
query.result:
136 The house from which your cry was born, 137 for the just disdain that has killed it 138 and put an end to your happy living,
139 was honored, it and its companions: 140 O Buondelmonte, how badly you fled 141 his wedding for the comforts of others!
142 Many would be happy, who are sad, 143 if God had granted you to Ema 144 the first time you came to the city.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
145 Ma conveniesi a quella pietra scema 146 che guarda ’l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse 147 vittima ne la sua pace postrema.
query.result: 145 But you were fitting to that senseless stone 146 that watches the bridge, that Florence made 147 a victim in its last peace.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
148 Con queste genti, e con altre con esse, 149 vid’ io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo, 150 che non avea cagione onde piangesse.
query.result: 148 With these people, and with others with them, 149 I saw Florence in such a rest 150 that it had no reason for which to weep.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
151 Con queste genti vid’io glorïoso 152 e giusto il popol suo, tanto che ’l giglio 153 non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,
154 né per divisïon fatto vermiglio».
query.result:
151 With these people I saw glorious 152 and just its people, so much that the lily 153 was never placed backwards on a staff,
154 nor made red by division.
